text: Ad-Hoc wireless is a point-to-point connection. Access Points (AP) are managed mode, and you'd need hostapd installing and configuring to operate an AP
This is a much better guide, and the recommended one https://help.ubuntu.com/community/WifiDocs/MasterMode
i have an atheros one!
I run an Ubuntu server here configured as the access point, it was quick to set up
so you can set a wireless network and share internet? i want to have internet through my external wireless dongle and send internet to my ihpone thought the internal wifi card
That's exactly how its used here - the server has 6 wired ethernet ports, the Wireless, and an embedded xDSL
do u know where can i read how to set up this laptop taht way?
Is the laptop connecting to the Internet via  wired connection?
no, via wireless external adapter
So does the laptop have *TWO* wifi adapters?
yes
OK, you can do it then
I've uploaded my server's hostpapd.conf file for you to see. If you 'sudo apt-get install hostapd' and copy/edit my config to your PC you're almost ready to go. http://iam.tj/files/
*hostapd.conf* ... typo!
You'll need to configure it for your atheros driver of course
everywhere i see a tutorial is for the following configuration: wired internet and wireless sharing interface.
Well, think slightly laterally. All those tutorials assume you've only got ONE wifi ... what they should say is 'how to configure for TWO separate interfaces'
yeah.. my internal wifi is called eth1 (weird) and the external one is wlan0
Think of your existing wireless connection to the Internet as being the 'wired' connection in those tutorials, and it makes sense
im afraid that if i configure that way my connection I wont be able to connect to another wifi. is that true? is easy to deactivate all that config im about to do?
Do you use the 2nd Wifi (wlan0) as a roaming connection then?
yes, sometimes i connect to another wireless networks
I've copied the entries you'd need in /etc/network/interfaces to my server too ... the file's called 'interfaces'
Could you change your procedures so you connect to those other WiFi networks using the internal wireless?
i cant, my internal adapter doesnt have enough gain, just to connect my mobile phone
OK, well then can't you swap things around so the external Wifi connects to the Internet router and roams, and you configure the internal WiFi as the AP for your phone?
correct
As an aside... if the internal wifi signal is that bad... it's likely that the antenna connectors inside the laptop have become disconnected. You might consider opening it up and checking on that!
im kinda lost, first i should install hostapd?
make sure you have the correct drivers for the internal wifi adapter first
i have them, i am sure because i have use them to connect before, right?

No! sometimes the driver firmware that has to be uploaded into the processor of the wifi chipset is different ... you need MASTER mode firmware, rather than just STATION mode... sometimes its combined; often not
i have a broadcom and a realtek
Broadcom could be a pig... not sure about realtek
dont worry is broadcom  4312
is the Broadcom the internal device you want to use as the AP?
broadcom is internal, realtek is the external one
im trying sudo iwconfig eth1 mode master and i get '
Sounds like you need additional driver firmware
'things just got real bro'
From the linux wireless web-site I see that the driver you need to use for Broadcom to support AP is the 'b43'
the realtek also has a problem, right? the message is the same from the wlan1 mode master command
Check this out, it's much more authoritative http://wireless.kernel.org/en/users/Documentation/modes
wow this is something sorta complex
i need to set master mode for my internal or external driver? the one in master mode is the one who would be the AP?
correct, so I guess that's the internal one
so the internal driver will be the one spreading wireless internet, but it will get it from the external one, right?
Correct

as long as the default gateway is configured correctly (as it should be automatically) packets from AP clients should be routed out on the other Wifi. what you need to be sure to do to avoid interference is to set the channel number of the AP as far away from your router's channel as possible.
Ideally put your home router on channel 1 and then, depending on your country limits, your AP on channel 11/13/14
cant find how to set master mode with the broadcom,just how to make it work, it already works!
Try installing and configuring hostapd then, see if it 'just works' !
Only if you reconfigure the interface you're currently using to access the Internet
done with the hostapd
Did it work?
well i dont know how to test it, the input is 'sudo iwconfig eth1 mode master' i keep getting 'sudo iwconfig eth1 mode master'
If you configure 'hostapd.conf' and 'interfaces' as in the files I uploaded for you, it should just work
You won't need any commands; the machine will configure itself correctly when it is started
wheres can i see the complete name of the driver?
From what I read you should be OK to use the default 'nl80211' as is in my hostapd.conf
so i just replace the file in that directory and then?
Edit the hostapd.conf I've provided where you see the ***.....*** parts
done
make sure you set a channel number that doesn't interfere with your home router
ok , done
Then you need to add to /etc/network/interfaces the contents of the 'interfaces' file I uploaded for you, too
You'll need to EDIT that interfaces section for wlan0 to ensure the addresses are the same as in your network, but on a different subnet to the other eth0 interface
so eth1 must be in a different subnet than wlan1 ?
Yes... I have my main wired LAN on 10.254.251.0/24 so I put the Wireless on 10.254.250.0/24
Then there's one thing left to do. You'll need to configure a lightweight DHCP server (dnsmasq) that will listen on the AP interface and issue IP addresses to clients
that kinda complex
How so? you want your clients to be able to talk to other don't you? without DHCP they won't be!
i could have a fixed Ip on my phone and i wont care
If you tell me your sub-net for wired and what you want to use for Wifi, I'll write you the /etc/dnsmasq.conf
OK... but it really would be better to just set it up to work automatically!
i dont us wired, just wireless for the access to the intenet AP and i wannt the mobile phone to get internet thoughr the laptop
sorry... I didn't mean wired I meant the internet eth0 interface :D
i added this to the interface file: iface eth0 inet static
that looks good
done, now what?
i dont see where would I put the interface in master mode
You don't, that's what hostapd does for you
how can i activate it?
restart hostapd with 'sudo service hostapd restart'
and check /var/log/syslog with the 'Log file viewer' to check for error or success messages
ok log file viewer? i havent use that, explain me how please
If you're using 12.04 with Unity  open the dash and type 'Log file viewer' to find it
its blank
should be installed by default :s
it is , butwhen i opened it its blank
LOL ok... thought you meant dash was blank. Use File > Open and choose /var/log/syslog
the file /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf its in blank too
How did you copy/edit my example to your system?
sudo gedit /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf
OK, that should do it, assuming you saved it
i mean, the file doesnt exist right now
If you save it using gedit it should do
ok, done, now i will restart service
OK ... good luck!
mmm done, aparently nothing happened
how do you test it?
i just type sudo service hostapd restart
nothing new in the syslog
OK... using that log file viewer, open the file /var/log/hostapd.log  and look for details
the same in 'sudo iwconfig eth1 mode master
OK... so we can work on that. That's the same error you got trying to use 'iwconfig' so it's likely a driver error
I need you to pastebin me the output of 'lspci -nn'
and also 'lsusb'
theres no  /var/log/hostapd.log
If you've configured the /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf correctly it should start and log something at least. You have installed hostapd haven't you ('sudo apt-get install hostapd') ?
yes
http://pastebin.com/RT8id2uN
thanks
And pastebin the output of 'iwconfig'
the folder was created for hostapd
This is what mine shows: http://paste.ubuntu.com/1163701/
http://pastebin.com/a37JdR08
you cant be the AP and get the internet int he same interface, right?
and you've specified 'eth1' in both /etc/network/interfaces and /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf  ?
correct... well it is technically possibly but hell to do!
I think the issue here is the BCM driver.
can you pastebin the output of 'sudo lspci -vvvnn -s 04:00.0'
http://pastebin.com/krEY3Tpi
whatis the interface that i need to set in interfaces and in hostadp?
that shows the driver is 'wl' ... we need to check that
it's 'eth1' currently
what can i do about this wl driver?
I'm researching it now
should i put in the config file of hostapd the wl drive?
no don't change anything
The 'wl' driver doesn't support master mode

You need to install the 'b43' driver. I'm reading that you need to do 'sudo apt-get install firmware-b43-installer' from this page: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/WifiDocs/Driver/bcm43xx#Installing_b43_drivers
you mean sudo apt-get install b43-fwcutter
no I don't
it's now 'firmware-b43-installer'
im following thar url instructions
At the start of the 'Installing b43 drivers' section it says 'Note: On Ubuntu 11.04 installing the 'firmware-b43-installer' package takes care of the downloading and installation of the b43 driver. '
If you're on 11.04, 11.10 or 12.04 then that's the package to use
ok, now i need to restart :/ i hate when that happens
you might not need to, you can manually load the driver after unloading the 'wl' driver
ive installed b43 and i still see wl, how to unload that?
at a command line, first ensure that 'wl' isn't in use by anything. Do 'lsmod | grep wl' and check that the number after 'wl' is zero
it is : 'lsmod | grep wl
That's good.  Now we can unload it: 'sudo rmmod wl'
check it's gone by doing 'lsmod | grep wl' once more
gone
Now we load the b43: 'sudo modprobe b43'
then check its in memory with 'lsmod | grep b43'
Kernel driver in use: b43-pci-bridge
sounds good
check the interfaces with 'iwconfig'
It's probably no longer eth1 and you'll need to change 'interfaces' and 'hostapd.conf' to reflect the new interface name
the same error when i try  sudo iwconfig wlan0 mode master
iwconfig shows the new interface as wlan0 then ?
pastebin me 'iwconfig' again please
http://pastebin.com/DpQM6akf
the command mode master shouldnt get a error message back
after you've fixed up the config files do 'sudo ifdown wlan0' then 'sudo service hostapd restart' and check the hostapd log file again
both config files should be with wlan0 interface?
yes
when i click in the upper corner icon, the broadcome says device not ready , firmware missing
should i change the driver=nl80211 line?
No
The message about the firmware is the clue.
ifdown: interface wlan0 not configured
that means the ' firmware-b43-installer' hasn't done its job, or else the firmware hasn't been uploaded to the device
that's fine
check the firmware files. pastebin me the directory listing 'ls -l /lib/firmware/brcm/'
http://pastebin.com/v9M6e6R2
its something bad with the driver? how can i erase it and dl again?
No it isn't, wait!
OK, there's an alternative for low-power devices.
remove the one you just installed 'sudo apt-get --purge remove firmware-b43-installer' and then install the low-power version 'sudo apt-get install firmware-b43-lpphy-installer'
downloading
ok, done...
broadcom is back online, the 'local' (ssid) is connected again
mode master command reply with an error still
does that interface report missing firmware now?
no
use log file viewer, look in /var/log/kern.log ... see if you see a recent message saying it's loading firmware
Yay!
ok, try restarting hostapd again
then look at the hostapd log file if its there
ok , done, nothing happened
no log entries?
theres no log
OK, that means there's something wrong with your config. Check in /var/log/syslog for any clues about it failing to start
NetworkManager[873]: <error> [1345775755.125846] [nm-device-wifi.c:1865] nm_device_wifi_set_mode(): (wlan0): error setting mode 2
OK... let me research that
this might help http://pastebin.com/v3AgAf0B
ahh! network manager needs to be told to not manage wlan0! you have to restart it. It'll ignore any interface listed in /etc/network/interfaces.
try this 'sudo service network-manager restart' then 'sudo service hostapd restart'
sudo service hostapd restart doesnt seem to do nothign,. nothigns added to the syslog log
now broadcom appears like device not managed
you didn't accidentally mistype it's config file name did you? I've done that before and wasted hours! :p
'not managed' is what you want. Don't want network-manager touching it
let me check
the file is in the directory /etc/hostapd and it has the following http://pastebin.com/Aj0LPgC4
your file looks good. We need therefore to find out why hostapd doesn't seem to be logging. lets find out if its in memory
shoudl i reinstall
do this 'ps -ef | grep hostapd' and you should see a line similar to this: 'root      4224     1  0 Aug20 ?        00:00:03 /usr/sbin/hostapd -B -P /var/run/hostapd.pid /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf'
why in iwconfig wlan0 is in managed mode?
that's the default mode until something changes it
mike     13237  4450  0 22:27 pts/0    00:00:00 grep --color=auto hostapd
ok... hostapd isn't starting then
that explains alot!
why not?
do this and pastebin me the results: 'sudo service hostapd start'
doesnt give something back
really? not even an error message?
nope. thats why i think it does nothing
the service command always reports any failure. that's where the problem is I think.
see http://paste.ubuntu.com/1163749/
Let's try the alternative method of controlling services. do 'sudo /etc/init.d/hostapd start'
should I reinstall?
the same: nothing
OK ... pastebin me this file 'cat /etc/default/hostapd'
http://pastebin.com/tgYCTWtW
HAHAHA slap me!
see that #DAEMON_CONF=''  and the text above it!?
My fault - I forgot I had to edit that... after all the time since I installed it I assumed it had that set originally!
yeah,,, uncooment it
i read it too jeje
so, 'gksudo gedit /etc/default/hostapd' and edit that line, remove the leading '#' and insert the name of the config file '/etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf'
Save it then finally START the service!
This is mine: http://paste.ubuntu.com/1163759/
* Starting advanced IEEE 802.11 management hostapd                      [fail]
the text is like this DAEMON_CONF='/etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf'
That's correct
it fails :/
Did it try to start?
if so, check the log :D
still no log for hostapd
did the service start say 'failed'
yes
OK, check /var/log/syslog it may say why
it doesnt add a new line when i try to restart
OK, let me check on mine for anything different
I wonder about the '+' at then end of your spa_passphrase. Try without it
its part of the password
That's in hostapd.conf
I know... but I'm looking for anything that might cause hostapd to barf
i thought its gonna be that but it failed too. still it addded some line to the log
it did? what was it?
http://pastebin.com/HC1GaFdJ
i dont understand what happened
pastebin the output of this: 'iw list  | grep -A 10 'Supported interface modes'  '
i dont have iw installed, i will do it
ahh!
im not a genius like u
http://paste.ubuntu.com/1163778/
Another YATY - AP mode is on that list
what do u mean?
although, we need to be sure that response was for wlan0 since you have two wifis.
try restarting hostapd now... It should have been installed in support of hostapd but seemingly wasnt
i did, it failes
OK
do this: 'sudo /usr/sbin/hostapd  /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf'
maybe pastebin the output if there is anything useful
/etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf
weird
channel?
try changing it in the config to 6 and try again
i change it to channel 6 in the .conf file and still the same error message
the same message  as above
let's enable lots of debug info. do this: 'sudo /usr/sbin/hostapd -dd  /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf'
I'll need it in pastebin... you might want to install 'pastebinit' and then run 'sudo /usr/sbin/hostapd -dd  /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf | pastebinit'
nice, i like that
http://paste.ubuntu.com/1163785/
mmmmm data... I'll be back :p
I *think* this may be to do with the channel width; 20MHz vs 40MHz ... I need to dig some more, give me a few minutes
channelwight isnt a standar?
40MHz channels are 802.11n ... doubles the available bandwidth but uses twice as many frequency bands
Got it! In hostapd.conf change 'ieee80211n=' from 1 to 0 ... save, and try it again
i got it
change 'ieee80211n=0'
We need to *disable* 40MHz channels
i did it with the -dd option and i unleashed hell
That means it works!
press Ctrl+C to kill that process
it kinda stuck, i dont like it
stuck?
it hasnt done its thing
Ctrl+C should terminate the process. If not, do Ctrl+D to suspend it
this is repeating in the log . Aug 23 23:25:26 pain-laptop kernel: [16528.204004] NOHZ: local_softirq_pending 08
if you have a command line after Ctrl+D then kill the suspended process using 'sudo kill %1'
im trying again
that NOHZ report is a known kernel bug, I'm checking on it
this is at the log pain-laptop kernel: [16646.440052] wlan0: no IPv6 routers present
it freezes at Using interface wlan0 with hwaddr 00:23:4e:df:52:45 and ssid 'local'
now it doenst even get to the NOHZ report
Is that after starting the service with 'sudo service hostapd start' ? And do you mean the PC freezes, or the hostapd log file?
the terminal just get there and theres no more entries at the log
that's the normal thing... normal service isn't generating all that debug info (there's no '-dd' on the command line any more)
ok, but does it take that long to start?
usually a couple of seconds or so
but still i dont know how to set the AP
You've set it, it's working.
if you every change the settings in hostapd.conf all you need do is issue a 'restart' to the service
how can i connect the mobile phone to the AP created?
i see it!! but i would like to see if i can have internet on my mobile phone
As I said, you'll need to configure the PC to forward packets to the internet and masquarade (NAT) them
the iphone doesnt finnish to connect to the AP
ok but i mean my mobile phone doesnt connect to the AP ive just created in ubuntu
are you giving it the correct passphrase?
yes, its in some kind of loop . hostapd: wlan0: STA 44:d8:84:0f:52:64 WPA: pairwise key handshake completed (RSN)
That's good
Remember I had you edit the pass-phrase; did you change it back?
look at this http://paste.ubuntu.com/1163803/
That looks the same as my AP
ok,, what if i want to deactivate the AP?}
Stop the service
ctrl+C  right
no!
You should now be running it using 'sudo service hostapd start'
or sudo /etc/init.d/hostapd stop
that puts it into the background and it runs as a service, no need for the terminal at all now
you can do that, but using 'service' is better in many ways
ok thanks very much! i need to sleep, tomorrow i will ask and learn more
